questions.question: A 3rd-year MBBS student is examining a case of deviated nasal septum. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: Nasal polyp will not be seen in a patient with deviated nasal septum. Clinical features of DNS: • Nasal obstruction - unilateral in C-shaped deviation and bilateral in S-shaped deviation • Headache - may be due to associated sinusitis or due to spur pressing on the lateral wall of the nose • Sinusitis - due to obstruction of ostia and poor ventilation of sinuses • Epistaxis - from vessels over spur or due to crusting of the nasal mucosa • Compensatory hypertrophy of turbinates on the roomier side • Anosmia - especially in bilateral nasal obstruction. Frequent middle ear infections • Association with external deformities

questions.question: What clinical test is depicted in the image?
questions.explanation: The clinical test depicted in the image is Cottle's test, where the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. This test is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve in patients with a deviated nasal septum. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve on that side. Option A: Epley's maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV. Epley's maneuver: return the patient to an upright, seated position with the neck flexed for 20-30 seconds. With the patient seated on the table, turn the head 45° toward the affected side while extending the neck. Lay the patient down, keeping the head rotated and extend the neck 10° to 20°, depending on the patient's ability and comfort. Hold this position for 20-30 seconds or until nystagmus ceases. Turn the head another 90°, rolling the body toward the unaffected side. Hold this position for 20-30 seconds or until nystagmus or vertigo ceases. Turn the head 90° toward the unaffected side. Hold this position for 20-30 seconds or until nystagmus or vertigo ceases. Option B: Heimlich maneuver is used in the treatment of accidental inhalation of a foreign body. Procedure: stand behind the person and place your arms around their lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs can dislodge the foreign body, providing some airway. Option D: Trotter's method is used in the treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter's method, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood. They should pinch the nose firmly for 5 to 10 minutes and breathe quietly from the mouth.

questions.question: An ENT surgeon is performing septoplasty in a patient with deviated nasal septum. Which ofthe following is not an indication for the surgery?
questions.explanation: Nasal discharge is not an indication for surgery in a patient with deviated nasal septum (DNS).Indications for surgery in DNS:•Symptoms of nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches•Recurrent sinusitis and otitis media• Recurrent epistaxis from the septal spur377• Septal deviation causing sleep apnea or hypopnoea syndromeOther indications for SMR (submucous resection) and septoplasty:••As a part of septorhinoplasty for cosmetic correction of external nasal deformitiesAs a preliminary step in hypophysectomy (trans-septal trans-sphenoidal approach) or vidianneurectomy (transseptal approach)• For the approach to middle meatus or frontal recess in endoscopic sinus surgery when deviatedseptum obstructs the view and access to these areas•To gain access for endoscopic dacryocystorhinostomy

questions.question: A patient diagnosed with deviated nasal septum is undergoing submucous resection. What isthe key incision is used in this procedure?
questions.explanation: Killian's incision is used in submucosal resection. It is a slightly curvilinear incision, taken 2-3mm above the caudal end of septal cartilage on the concave side of the deviated nasal septum.Option B: Shobinger incision is used in modified radical neck dissection.Option C: Freer's hemitransfixation incision is used in septoplasty. It is a septocolumellar incisiontaken between the caudal end of septal cartilage and columella.Option D: Weber Ferguson incision is used in maxillectomy.Killian's and Hemitransfixion incisionKillian'sincision-HemitransfixionincisionOMARROW

questions.question: A 20-year-old college student presented with complaints of facial pain, nasal discharge, headache, and nasal bleeding. He has a history of recurrent sinusitis in the past. On anterior rhinoscopy examination, the nasal septum is deviated. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is a case of deviated nasal septum and septoplasty is the treatment of choice. Both submucous resection and septoplasty can be done for DNS. Septoplasty is a conservative approach and more commonly done nowadays. Septoplasty is also the preferred surgery for DNS in less than 18 years, if DNS is bilateral and severe. Submucous resection: Non-conservative procedure with extensive dissection of cartilage. Not done in < 18 years. Killian's incision is used. Septoplasty: Conservative procedure. Can be done in adults and persons < 18 years if bilateral and severe. Freer's incision is used. Mucoperichondrial/periosteal flaps raised on only one side. Flaps raised on both sides of the septum. More complications. Reoperation is difficult. Less complications. Reoperation is easier.

questions.question: A mother brought her 5-year-old child with complaints of pain and swelling in the nose anddifficulty in breathing after an alleged history of fall while playing. On examination, there isbilateral swelling of the nasal septum which is tender and erythematous. Which of thefollowing is false about the given condition?

options.B: Can result in hump nose deformity
options.D: Accumulation of blood under the perichondrium

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with bilateral septal swelling following trauma is suggestive of a septalhematoma and can result in saddle nose deformity, not hump nose deformity.Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasalseptum. It is caused due to trauma, septal surgery, and bleeding disorders. Clinical featuresinclude pain, swelling, and bilateral nasal obstruction (the most common presenting feature), and379sometimes, frontal headache.Complications include septal abscess, depression of dorsum (saddle nose), and permanentlythickened septum.

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy fell from the bed and developed swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing. Which of the following is the best management for this child?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with swelling in the nose after trauma is suggestive of septal hematoma and it needs immediate surgical drainage. Treatment of septal hematoma: • Aspiration of small hematomas • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of septal perforation?
questions.explanation: Trauma is the most common cause of septal perforation.Causes of septal perforation:• Trauma - nasal surgery, nose picking, septal cauterization, nasal packing, septal hematoma,foreign bodies• Surface irritants cocaine, heroin, decongestant nasal sprays• Infections syphilis, typhoid, tuberculosis, lepromatous leprosy, rhinosporidiosis,-rhinoscleroma, aspergillosis• Neoplastic melanoma, SCC, adenocarcinoma, lymphoma• Inflammatory - sarcoidosis, Crohn's disease, RA, Granulomatosis with polyangitisSmall anterior perforations may present with a whistling sound during respiration. Largeperforations may obstruct the nose or even bleed due to the formation of crusts.Treatment depends on the cause. Small asymptomatic perforations can be closed by plastic flaps.In larger perforations treatment is aimed at keeping the nose crust-free using nasal douches andbland ointments.

questions.question: A middle-aged man with tertiary syphilis presented with complaints of epistaxis, nasal crusting, and nasal twang on speaking. On examination, nasal septal perforation was noted. What is the most likely site for the perforation?

options.D: Junction of the bony and cartilaginous septum

questions.explanation: The given patient is having nasal septal perforation due to syphilis. The most common site of involvement in syphilis is the bony nasal septum. Other chronic granulomatous conditions like lupus, tuberculosis, and leprosy can cause perforation in the cartilaginous part. Wegener's granulomatosis causes perforation of both bony and cartilaginous parts.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman from a rural area presented with foul-smelling nasal discharge, nasalcrusts, and epistaxis. She was diagnosed with atrophic rhinitis. On examination, maggotswere seen in the nasal cavity. Which of the following is used in the treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: Myiasis (maggots in the nasal cavity) is a complication of atrophic rhinitis. It is treated withchloroform diluted with water.The maggots are larval forms of flies especially genus Chrysomia. The flies are attracted by thefoul-smelling nasal discharge in conditions like atrophic rhinitis, syphilis, leprosy, and lay eggs inthe nasal cavity. These eggs hatch into larvae within 24 hrs and cause intense irritation,lacrimation, sneezing, and blood-tinged nasal discharge.Treatment:• All visible maggots should be picked up with forceps• Instillation of chloroform water and oil kills them•Nasal douche with warm saline is used to remove slough, crusts, and dead maggots.

questions.question: Bernoulli's phenomenon explains the pathogenesis of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Bernoulli's phenomenon explains the pathogenesis of nasal polyp formation.Bernoulli's principle states that when the velocity of air increases, the lateral pressure willdecrease. When air passes through the nasal valve area which is the narrowest region of the nasalcavity, velocity increases. This creates a negative pressure that sucks mucosa of sinuses into thenasal cavity leading to polyp formation.

questions.question: 372A 45-year-old man was prescribed aspirin for post-MI prophylaxis. But whenever he takes themedication, he develops difficulty in breathing, sneezing, and lacrimation. He has a knownfamily history of bronchial asthma. Which of the following is related to the his condition?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Samter's triad where the patient will have aspirin intolerance,asthma, and ethmoidal polyps.Other etiological factors of ethmoidal polyp:• Chronic rhinosinusitis especially non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome• Allergic fungal sinusitis• Asthma• Cystic fibrosis• Kartagener syndrome - This consists of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus and ciliarydyskinesis• Young syndrome - It consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia•Churg-Strauss syndrome - Consists of asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis and granuloma381

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman came to the OPD with complaints of bilateral nasal obstruction, headache, sneezing, and nasal discharge. On examination, multiple smooth pale glistening masses are present bilaterally that don't bleed on touch. Which of the following is false about the diagnosis?

options.B: The site of origin is the lateral wall of the nose
options.C: FESS is the treatment of choice
options.D: The mass can grow posteriorly and occupy the choana

questions.explanation: The given case scenario with multiple bilateral nasal masses in a middle-aged woman is suggestive of ethmoidal polyp, and it doesn't grow posteriorly to occupy the choana.

questions.question: You are an intern examining a child who presented with nasal obstruction and discharge. Onanterior rhinoscopy, there is a single smooth glistening mass in the right nasal cavity whichcan be moved up and down with a probe and doesn't bleed on touch. The mass is extendingposteriorly and occupying the choana. Which of the following is false regarding thiscondition?

options.A: Infection and allergy are the main etiological factors
options.B: The site of origin is maxillary antrum
options.C: FESS is the treatment of choice

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with findings of a single, unilateral polyp that extends posteriorly tooccupy the choana in a child is suggestive of antrochoanal polyp. It can present with hyponasalvoice and not hypernasal voice.

questions.question: A middle-aged man with recurrent diffuse ethmoidal polyps is scheduled for a laser-assisted FESS procedure. Which of the following lasers is ideal in this scenario?
questions.explanation: KTP laser (potassium titanyl phosphate) is the ideal laser for the treatment of nasal polyps. Option A: Nd-YAG laser, due to its greater depth of penetration, has a higher risk of complications within the nasal cavity. Option C: CO2 lasers are primarily used for laryngeal interventions. Their use in nasal sinus surgery is restricted as they cause extensive scarring and cannot be delivered through a flexible fiber-optical system. Option D: The use of argon lasers is limited in sinus surgery due to the high cost of the laser tube and the need for a high current power supply and water flow for cooling.
